newsitem.title: RUSSIA: No risk from plutonium in failed Mars probe - Russia.
newsitem.headline: No risk from plutonium in failed Mars probe - Russia.

text.p: Russian officials on Monday said there would be no risk from deadly plutonium which fell to earth after their Mars-96 probe failed on Saturday, but admitted the mishap was a blow to the Russian space programme.

"It is a terrible blow for all of us...We put a lot of hope into this mission, a mission which has no parallel in the world," Yuri Milov, director of Russian Space Agency's automated flight programme told a news conference.
Russia launched its Mars-96 probe from the Baikonur cosmodrome in Kazakhstan on Saturday. But the planned 10-month mission failed hours after lift-off and the six-tonne probe tumbled towards earth.
Milov said the probe was carrying 270 grams (10 ounces) of plutonium 238, a very potent carcinogen that causes lung and bone cancer if inhaled.
But he insisted that tiny canisters used to hold the deadly material would not pose any threat after the destruction of the probe.
"The production process does not allow its breakdown in any extraordinary situation," he said. "There is no danger that the isotope will disintegrate."
Mars-96 was Earth's second mission to the Red Planet in less than two weeks. It aimed to find about more about the possibility that there once was life on Mars.
Milov said he had no reason yet for the failure of the mission. "We have got to look at all the information," he said.
Experts say that most of the probe probably burned up when it re-entered the earth's atmosphere, but some parts could have crashed into the sea off Chile.
A Chilean navy officer said there was little chance that any of the debris would be recovered because the sea around the crash site was very deep.
U.S. scientists said plutonium 238 had no military uses and has a half-life of 87.5 years, much shorter than other radioactive materials which stay radioactive for thousands of years.
